ai-ud8.7:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was traveling along the road between in the Kosalan lands with Venerable Nāgasamāla as his second monk.
ai-ud8.7:1.3_0: The venerable Nāgasamāla saw the way road between the two tracks
ai-ud8.7:1.4_0: and after seeing (him), he said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud8.7:1.7_0: After that was said, the Fortunate One said this to venerable Nāgasamāla:
ai-ud8.7:2.2_0: For a third time venerable Nāgasamāla said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud8.7:2.5_0: And for a third time the Buddha responded,
ai-ud8.7:2.8_0: Then Nāgasamāla put the Buddha’s bowl and robes down on the ground right there and left, saying,
ai-ud8.7:2.9_0: “Sir, here are your bowl and robes.”
ai-ud8.7:3.1_0: Then as Nāgasamāla was going down that road, he was set upon by bandits who struck him with fists and feet, broke his bowl, and tore up his outer robe.
ai-ud8.7:3.2_0: Then Venerable Nāgasamāla, with his broken bowl and torn double-robe
ai-ud8.7:3.3_0: While sat on one side venerable Nāgasamāla said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud8.7:3.4_0: “Just now, sir, as I was traveling from that road, I left my bowl and took the bowl with my hands and feet.”
ai-ud8.7:4.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud8.7:5.2_0: the knowledge master mixes with foolish folk.
ai-ud8.7:5.3_0: Having understood (that), he abandons bad deeds,
ai-ud8.7:5.4_0: like a milk-drinking heron the water.”
